guards.name: Closed Guard
guards.description: The full guard, also known as the closed guard, is one of BJJ’s strongest positions. Full guard is basically an upside-down mount position for the person on the bottom. In full guard, the individual in the bottom position wraps his or her legs around the person on top. From full guard, the bottom player can defend strikes, apply submissions, and initiate sweeps. The full guard is a great BJJ, MMA, and self-defense position.

guards.name: Deep Half
guards.description:
What does the deep half guard look like? In the position, you’re lying on your back, your shoulders directly underneath the middle of your opponent’s hips. You control one of their legs, which is extended. By wrapping your own legs around it, most often in a hook configuration or a triangle, and you use your arms to establish grips at the hip level of the same leg.

 The other leg of your opponent is bent, and your head rests on the thigh. In certain situations, you can also use one of your arms to control the hip on that side.

guards.name: De La Riva
guards.description: Popularised by Ricardo de la Riva, the De La Riva guard is mostly played on your back against standing opponents by hooking your leg around of your opponent's leading leg (e.g. if your opponent leads with their right leg, your left leg wraps behind it from the outside). A wide number of sweeps and transitions can be employed from this position while also limiting your opponent's mobility and attacking options.

guards.name: Half Guard
guards.description: The half guard is the position that is in between a full guard and side control or full mount. The combatant on top will try to untangle the leg and pass to obtain side control or mount, while the bottom combatant will try to transition into a full guard or alternatively attempt a sweep or submission.
